Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: VCSELA Wireless Technology
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will be to develop a higher power light source for wireless infrastructure links of high power and high speed. Typically, these links depend on mechanical alignment, presenting challenges such as a large form factor, increased use of power, and slow response. The proposed project will use non-mechanical methods to steer a beam. This development of these light sources will enable optical wireless links that are both easier to align and more stable, thus representing an important and inexpensive source for future high-speed links.

This Phase I project advances a novel compound semiconductor laser array integrated with a high-speed electrical waveguide and integrated micro-optical lenses on the back side of the chip to sum beams into an overlap intensity profile. This low coherent source can be designed to increase power out without a penalty in frequency response. The proposed project enables non-mechanical beam steering using an array of array; the device will direct the beam using a routing technique with passive optical offsets. Efforts will be to understand and design optical intensity profiles in the far field and develop the capability to non-mechanically switch or sequence the arrays to move the data beam, to auto-align the beam's fine tuning. Optical modeling of the micro-optical lens arrays on the opposite side of a back-emitter laser array structure will enable understanding the light intensity and bit error rate uniformity fields at the collector. The design process will optimize overlap areas in the near field where uniform intensity is critical for projecting into the far field for collector stability. These devices could yield high-speed LiFi emitters ideal for wireless links, either for long distance or point-to-multipoint connections.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF SEED FUND PHASE I 2015136 -Outcome

OPTICAL WIRELESS NON-MECHANICAL BEAM STEERING

This NSF funded effort demonstrated a non-mechanical steerable high-power light source for Gbps class optical wireless fronthaul infrastructure links. The objectives of Phase I were met and the results indicate a potential device or product is possible with high value to wireless commercial communications markets. 

Wireless connections typically have a speed and distance metric which has dominated connectivity limitations and infrastructure capabilities. The limitation is based on Radio Frequency (RF) Wireless material penetration vs speed of data transfer. A long-distance connection must use low frequency (to go farther) and hence determines the low bandwidth connection speed.  New products are being offered at higher frequencies which offer higher bandwidths approaching 10Gbps, but come with the complexity of not going as far, (hundreds of meters) and the complexity of Line of Sight (LOS) connections.  As RF connection speeds approach the LOS barrier there is no comparison to a new LOS wireless photonics NIR light source.

OptiPulse has demonstrated a new compound semiconductor chip architecture which can take a signal and turns it into a powerful and fast NIR Light based wireless emitter (invisible and eye-safe).   The low coherence high optical power sources are ideal for long distance very fast data transfer. Chips are being tested at 25Gbps in single channel narrow NIR bands. Chips are processed in Bulk that will cost $1/chip.  A single chip can form a wireless connection of multiple kilometers at multi-Gbps and use very little energy.

This new compound semiconductor technology could potentially disrupt current communications infrastructure deployments.  The cost, energy effiency and performance creates a new paradigm of 6G Optical Wireless connections for high speed data transfer.

The development of the optical wireless network has several milestones that reduce the costs to deploy a robust and autonomously aligned mesh network for bandwidth distribution. The reduction of infrastructure costs directly impacts the number of people that will be connected to this new network. One cost reducing engineering development would be to eliminate the need for a gimbal to direct the beam of light for mainly automatic alignment. If this could be done on the chip scale it would drastically change the dynamics of cost for deployment.  

This NSF Phase I demonstrates the ability to direct these new optical beams through an electrical switching rather than a two-axis mechanical gimbal necessary for that capability.  RF mmWave which has LOS limitations has developed a phased array technique which steers the beam non mechanically and is what 5G network connections are currently based on. 

Phase I demonstrated offsetting microlens to arrayed lasers can result in a summed beam direction change like the direction change in phased mmWave arrays. The array of microlens radially offset to direct beams to an overlap point on the Z axis was characterized with near field beam profiles. This overlap point created by those offsets can also be applied to direct the beam in x and y from the normal beam exit angle. The corresponding offset to direction change is ~1um offset for each 1o change in beam direction. This result demonstrates the capability to produce a valuable cost lowering component for optical wireless automated beam alignment. The product may be a central component in the ability to autonomously aligning beams using electrical switching which could dramatically reduce wireless high bandwidth costs. 

Fig. 1 Chip AEC (The E designation is a 90o incident angle from surface) and was tested for speed and BER using emitter drive and detector circuit boards designed for Prototype 3. A video was shot with 10Gbps performance from high speed scope. Measured BER at 65 meters indoors was <1E 10-12 or virtually no errors.  The video is available from Optipulse and can be seen by visiting website.

Phase I clearly showed lasers propagation through an offset GaAs semiconductor etched optical element can direct beams statically. Lasers can be positioned relative to Microlenses and offset radially from the centroid resulting in an overlap point of the beams on the Z axis, either real or virtual. This overlaps the beams in front or behind chip to a uniform high intensity spot. A macro lens can then be positioned with its F.P. positioned at that same overlap point projecting the summed beams uniform power density into the far filed for high speed detection.  VCSELA laser structures normally have a 90o incident propagation from the surface. 

OptiPulse’s technology has demonstrated advantages over common FSOC systems including wide angle beams produced high bandwidth by a wafer scale device that can use non-mechanical steering, reducing size, cost and energy usage.

Phase II will improve the resolution of the beam steering by confirming current designs, designing, and producing arrays to form beam steering module platform capable of replacing a gimbal in many use cases.
